column1: Title
column4: Partners
column5: Description

column1: SDGs in Practice Opening Segment
column4: UNITAR
column5: The opening session of the 2025 SDGs in Practice will be held in person on 14 July from 11:00 AM to1:00 PM (Conference Room 11). This session will focus on advancing capacities and providing learning opportunities to support the HLPF 2025 theme: “Advancing sustainable, inclusive, scienceand evidence-based solutions for the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and its Sustainable Development Goals for leaving no one behind”.

column1: From HIV to Health for All: Accelerating SDG 3 Through Practical Partnerships and Solutions
column4: UNAIDS, WHO, UNICEF, UNDP, UNFPA, UN Women
column5: Focusing on universal health coverage, this session addressed stalled progress in maternal health and immunization, rising NCDs and mental health burdens, and persistent inequalities—especially for women and girls. Convened by UNAIDS in collaboration with WHO, UNICEF, UNDP, UNFPA and UN Women, the discussion moved from diagnosis to action, sharing scalable cross‑sector tools and partnership models grounded in Voluntary National Review (VNR) / UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF) evidence. Participants, including governments, civil society, communities, and UN actors, explored how gender‑responsive health systems and integrated approaches can accelerate progress on SDG 3 in the final stretch to 2030.

column1: Accelerating progress on SDG 5
column4: UNWOMEN
column5: Led by UN Women, this interactive session brought together experts, practitioners, and advocates to examine how best to advance gender equality and empower women and girls. The session provided a platform to share the latest data, promising practices, and brainstorm on realistic pathways to accelerate progress on Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 5. Drawing on the Regional Forums on Sustainable Development momentum and Beijing+30, the session used presentations, breakout rooms, and peer learning to surface innovations, practices, and tools that mainstream gender across policies and financing. It equipped a broad audience with practical pathways to accelerate transformative, intersectional progress.

column1: Green Growth and Resilience Building
column4: CANEUS, Inspire 4 Tomorrow Foundation, FILAC and Pawanka Fund
column5: Against the triple planetary crisis and ongoing shocks, this session explored embedding green growth and resilience transitions into national policies, industry practice, and community action. Themes included STI‑driven transformation, resilient infrastructure and nature‑based solutions, financing mechanisms, and multi‑stakeholder partnerships. Participants were introduced to tools and methodologies—such as the Enhanced Voluntary Local Review for Green Growth and Resilient Transition (UN DESA) and Re’Planet Ecosystem Country-led Implementation Model —and case studies to support inclusive, climate‑aligned development.

column1: A Sustainable Blue Planet: Protecting, Innovating and Educating
column4: Oceano Azul  Foundation, Oceanário de Lisboa
column5: This ocean‑focused session highlighted urgent actions to scale marine protected areas (toward 30x30), advance a regenerative blue economy (e.g., blue biotechnology), elevate ocean issues in global agendas (including BBNJ ratification and ocean NDCs), and embed ocean literacy via a “Blue Curriculum.” Tools and examples included Blue Azores, BlueBioValue, the UN‑Portugal Ocean Fellowship, the RISE UP movement, and Educating a Blue Generation. It connected conservation, livelihoods, education, and advocacy to accelerate SDG 14.

column1: Inclusive Policies and Stakeholder Engagement for the 2030 Agenda
column4: International Disability Alliance (IDA), Commonwealth Medical Trust (Commat), Women’s	Major Group (WMG)
column5: Addressing the gap between inclusion rhetoric and practice, this session showcased concrete ways to embed marginalized voices—especially persons with disabilities and women—into SDG policy cycles and VNRs. Solutions spanned community‑led data and shadow reporting, accessible consultation frameworks (IDA/WMG), capacity‑building (Commat), and collaboration models that improve accountability. Interactive elements (polling, shared tools) supported participants to adapt inclusive methodologies within national contexts.

column1: Building country capacity for multi-stakeholder partnerships
column4: RCO Mexico, The Partnering Initiative
column5: Focusing on country‑level delivery of SDG 17, this session provided practical tools—developed through the Partnership Accelerator and field experience (e.g., Mexico, Sri Lanka)—to strengthen professional partnering capabilities and trust‑based collaboration. Featured tools included national partnership landscape mapping, guidance on running National Partnership Forums, and partnership ideation workshops to build momentum and co‑create solutions. Format blended frameworks, fireside chats with RCO experts, and breakouts.

column1: Strategic Foresight for Sustainable Development: Future-proofing Policy and Partnerships
column4: No
column5: This training demonstrated how World Population Prospects (WPP) and World Economic Situation and Prospects (WESP) can shift planning from reactive to proactive. Through videos, expert presentations, and Q&A, participants learned to apply demographic and economic projections to workforce planning, social protection, macroeconomic stability, and sustainable growth. UN DESA’s broader Future in Focus offerings were highlighted as a consolidated foresight toolkit for Member States.

column1: Accelerating SDG 8: Investing in Decent Jobs and Just Transitions Through the Global Accelerator
column4: ILO, partners of the Global Accelerator on Jobs and Social Protection for Just Transitions (GA) and its Technical Support Facility (FAO, UNDP, UNICEF, UN Women, WFP)
column5: Amid uneven SDG 8 progress, this session spotlighted the Global Accelerator on Jobs and Social Protection for Just Transitions—one of the 12 High Impact Initiatives of the 2023 SDG Summit—as a vehicle to fast‑track decent work and universal social protection. It covered integrated policy/financing solutions via the Technical Support Facility, showcased pathfinder country experiences (18 committed) and donor backing (Belgium, Germany, Ireland, Korea, Spain), and emphasized rights‑based, coherent action linking jobs, protection, and just transitions.

column1: Investing in multi-stakeholder Partnerships for the SDGs
column4: RCO Mexico, The Partnering Initiative
column5: Building on the Unite to Ignite study, this session examined why multi-stakeholder partnerships need financing approaches distinct from traditional projects and how funders can invest both in partnerships and the enabling environment (policies, institutional capacities, engagement mechanisms). It guided donors, foundations, development banks, companies, and governments on who funds, what instruments (grants, finance, blended), how to structure support for adaptive, collective impact, and what internal changes funders need to become effective multi-stakeholder partnership backers. A Mexico case illustrated investing in partnership infrastructure and capacities.

column1: Digital Platforms and Data Innovation for SDG Implementation and Monitoring
column4: UN Statistics Division in collaboration with several national statistics office representatives
column5: Showcasing how countries close SDG data gaps, this session featured a live demo of the UN Data Platform and national experiences: Statistics Korea (digital innovation), Palestine (geospatial data for policy), Dominican Republic (non‑traditional data for extreme events), and the UK (Open SDG customization). It highlighted integrating administrative, geospatial, citizen, and other innovative sources to improve timeliness, disaggregation, and policy relevance while maintaining NSO‑led quality and coherence.

column1: Advancing Inclusive Data Systems: Strengthening Citizen Data for Impact
column4: Citizen Data, UN Statistics Division, UN Women, Open Data Watch, World Bank, UNITAR, PARIS21, Stakeholder Group of Persons with Disabilities, International Civil Society Centre
column5: This full‑day workshop marked the UN Statistical Commission’s 2025 endorsement of the Copenhagen Framework on Citizen Data, recognizing citizen data within national data ecosystems. Four sessions covered: implementing the Framework (incl. new e‑learning), gender & citizen data (Participation for Transformation Model; cases from Ethiopia, Senegal, Mexico), intersectional & disability data (organizations of persons with disabilities experiences, World Federation of the Deaf), and integration with official sources (cases from Saint Lucia, Colombia, Ghana; Data2Policy). Discussions stressed quality, interoperability, governance, and trust to scale inclusive data for SDG monitoring and decision‑making.

column1: Opening segment The Crucial Role of Training and Learning for Advancing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development
column4: UNITAR
column5: In 2024, seven SDG in Practice sessions will be organized in the margins of HLPF, covering topics such as the Future of Education and Artificial Intelligence, Partnership Building and MultiStakeholder Engagement, Driving the national transformations we need: lessons from the Global Sustainable Development Report, Climate Change, Biodiversity Loss and Pollution, Data Collection and Analysis for SDG Monitoring, and Harnessing Citizen-Generated Data for SDG and VNR Monitoring and Evaluation. The SDGs in Practice training sessions are open to all interested parties and are organized by UN entities in collaboration with a range of partners and stakeholders. The opening segment for the SDGs in Practice will be held in person, bringing together a range of experts involved in the fulfillment of the SDGs and the 2030 Agenda, focusing on the overarching topic of “Th

column1: Future of Education and Artificial Intelligence
column4: UNESCO International Institute for Higher Education in Latin America and the Caribbean (IESALC)
column5: UNESCO IESALC is offering a 2-hour online training on The Future of Education and Artificial Intelligence (AI) to explore how AI is transforming teaching, learning, research, and institutional management. The session brings together Member States and stakeholders to discuss opportunities, challenges, and strategies for integrating AI into education systems. Key themes include ethics, capacity building, digital infrastructure, social inclusion, and youth and female leadership. Through dialogue and scenario workshops, participants will co-develop recommendations to ensure equitable, innovative, and sustainable digital transformations in education.

column1: Partnership building and multi-stakeholder engagement for the 2030 Agenda
column4: The Partnering Initiative, and Partnerships2030
column5: On 9 July 2024, UN DESA, The Partnering Initiative, and Partnerships2030 will host a virtual session on Partnership Building and Multi-Stakeholder Engagement for the 2030 Agenda. The event will explore how diverse actors can align interests, pool resources, and develop transformative partnerships to achieve the SDGs. Participants will be guided through frameworks, tools, and strategies to build sustainable, system-changing collaborations that no single entity could achieve alone

column1: Driving the national transformations we need: lessons from the Global Sustainable Development Report
column4: UN Development Coordination Office and UN Development Programme
column5: On 10 July 2024, UN DESA/DSDG, in collaboration with the UN Development Coordination Office and UNDP, will host a virtual session on Driving the National Transformations We Need: Lessons from the Global Sustainable Development Report (GSDR). The event will examine the 2023 GSDR’s findings on the lack of progress toward the SDGs and the need for systemic approaches that identify synergies, manage trade-offs, and accelerate transformations. Participants will explore how evidence, networks, and tools can support integrated national strategies for sustainable development.

column1: Climate Change, Biodiversity Loss, and Pollution
column4: UN Office for Disaster Risk Reduction, and UN Environment Programme
column5: On 10 July 2024, UN DESA, UNDRR, and UNEP will convene a virtual session on Climate Change, Biodiversity Loss, and Pollution, addressing the interlinked “triple planetary crisis” and its implications for the SDGs. The discussion will highlight how climate change, biodiversity, and pollution intersect with poverty, health, food security, and sustainable cities, while exploring governance, science-policy integration, and inclusive partnerships. Participants will examine pathways to accelerate action, strengthen resilience, and foster sustainable, equitable solutions.

column1: Jobs and Social Protection
column4: ILO – International Labour Organisation
column5: On 11 July 2024, the International Labour Organization (ILO) will host a virtual session on Jobs and Social Protection. The event will explore how social protection, decent job creation, and labour market policies can foster resilience, reduce inequality, and ensure just transitions in the face of digital, demographic, and climate-related shifts. Drawing on the UN Global Accelerator on Jobs and Social Protection for Just Transitions, the session will highlight country-level approaches, financing strategies, and solutions to expand coverage, formalize work, and support vulnerable groups.

column1: Data Collection and Analysis for SDG Monitoring
column4: UN Statistics Division and Data Diplomacy Academy
column5: On 11 July 2024, the UN Statistics Division and the Data Diplomacy Academy will host a virtual session on Data Collection and Analysis for SDG Monitoring. The event will explore how official and citizen-generated data, combined with innovative tools and data diplomacy, can strengthen SDG monitoring and policymaking. Special focus will be given to the energy transition (SDG 7), with discussions on the role of inclusivity, transparency, and international collaboration in building accurate, equitable, and actionable data systems.

column1: Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions
column4: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) and United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)
column5: On 12 July 2024, UNODC and UNDP will host a virtual session on Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions. The event will focus on strengthening institutional integrity and accountability through tools such as corruption risk management, anti-corruption frameworks, and survey-based indicators for SDG 16. Participants will explore practical approaches to prevent corruption, enhance transparency, and improve service delivery, contributing to more effective and trustworthy institutions worldwide.

column1: Harnessing Citizen-Generated Data for SDG and VNR Monitoring and Evaluation
column4: Collaborative on Citizen Data
column5: On 17 July 2024, the Collaborative on Citizen Data, co-led by the UN Statistics Division, World Bank, and UN Women, will host an in-person/hybrid workshop on Harnessing Citizen-Generated Data for SDG and VNR Monitoring and Evaluation in New York. The workshop will explore how citizen data can fill gaps, enhance inclusivity, and inform policymaking and programmatic actions. Participants will engage with the draft Copenhagen Framework on Citizen Data, share best practices, and examine tools and methods for ethical, safe, and effective citizen data collection and use to support sustainable development.

column1: Opening session on accelerating recovery from COVID-19 and implementing the 2030 Agenda
column4: UNITAR
column5: the opening session addressed the 2023 SDG Learning, Training, and Practice, focusing on the UN High-Level Political Forum's theme of accelerating recovery from COVID-19 and implementing the 2030 Agenda. The session highlighted the challenges faced, progress made, and the need for international cooperation and funding for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals.

column1: Paradigm shift: tools to ensure best practice when engaging marginalized communities and youth
column4: International Movement ATD Fourth World and Fundação Antonio Meneghett
column5: This session focused on SDG 17 (Partnership for the goals) and emphasized that achieving the 2030 Agenda relies on involving poverty-affected communities and youth in designing solutions. This session examined effective tools to advance multiple SDGs, while fostering equitable participation and ethical collaboration. This session also encouraged inclusive policy-making, amplifying the voices of impacted communities and youth

column1: Resilience in a time of crisis: Transforming Energy access, Climate Action Learning and strengthening indigenous knowledge to achieve the SDGs
column4: Transforming Energy Access Learning Partnership (TEA-LP), University of Cape Town, International Association for the Advancement of Innovative Approaches to Global Challenges IAAI GloCha, CANEUS Pawanka Fund, FILAC and UNITAR
column5: Focusing on SDG 7 (Affordable and clean energy), this virtual session featured objectives including: leveraging expertise from multistakeholder partners; introduce cutting-edge methodologies, including practical examples such as energy access education for SDG 7, Indigenous knowledge research infrastructure, green growth strategies, and blockchainenabled climate action learning; fostering collaboration; sharing of lessons and practices, and promoting a global movement for climate education and local SDGs empowerment.

column1: Sustainability in Action: The Role of Facility Management and Electrotechnology’s Impact on the SDGs - A New Story
column4: IFMA Foundation, International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC)
column5: This session focused on SDG 17 (Partnership for the goals), and discussed in depth the role of facility management in addressing global challenges, indoor air quality's impact, and how management facilities contribute to implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals.

column1: SDG Synergies: a tool to support decision making in implementing the 2030 Agenda
column4: Stockholm Environment Institute (SEI
column5: With a focus on SDG 17 (Partnership for the goals), this virtual session aimed at enhancing the adoption and capability to utilize SDG Synergies, targeting government, academia, and civil society stakeholders worldwide, utilizing the HLPF as a platform to showcase the potential of SDG Synergies in understanding cross-impact interactions among the SDGs. The session included a training workshop to facilitate skill development, peer collaboration, and networking, by presenting the tool's features, usage, case studies, and access instructions.

column1: Building Sustainable Cities: Harnessing the potential of local communities to withstand crises
column4: Cities Alliance Slum Dwellers International (SDI), Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC), United Cities and Local Governments (UCLG), Women in Informal Employment, Globalizing and Organizing (WIEGO)
column5: Targeted on both SDG 11 (Sustainable cities and communities) and SDG 17 (Partnership for the goals), this session encouraged peer learning and idea exchange among urban actors, focused on locally-led strategies for response, recovery, and resilience-building in cities, and aimed at promoting equitable development and inclusivity. The session reviewed methodologies to facilitate knowledge and best practice sharing related to successful urban recovery and resilience approaches, while also fostering collaboration and partnerships among various stakeholders including local authorities, community-based organizations, government agencies, NGOs, to enhance coordinated efforts and resource leverage for sustainable recovery and resilience

column1: Accelerating resilient recovery: Role of Infrastructure Sector and Entrepreneurship
column4: UN-Habitat, UNCTAD, International Anti-Corruption Academy (IACA), Think Tank AlterContacts
column5: Focused on SDG 11 (Sustainable cities and communities) and SDG 17 (Partnership for the goals), this virtual session explored pathways for resilient post COVID-19 recovery by leveraging the SDG Cities Global Initiative, transparent infrastructure development, and urban entrepreneurship. Through interactive discussions, digital tools introduction, presentation of corruption prevention tools, and sharing insights on urban expansion, the session aimed to promote institutional synergies for implementing the 2030 Agenda by addressing sustainable city acceleration, corruption risks in infrastructure, urban entrepreneurs' role in innovation, and lessons from pandemic-resilient entrepreneurs.

column1: Enabling effective multi-stakeholder partnerships for the Sustainable Development Goals
column4: The Partnering Initiative Partnerships2030
column5: Through the lenses of SDG 17 (Partnership for the goals), this session discussed how to enhance awareness and capacity in developing partnership factors for multistakeholder collaborations in support of the SDGs, facilitated by the 2030 Agenda Partnership Accelerator, Partnerships2030, and the Global Forum on SDG Advisory Bodies. This training concentrated on individual and institutional partnering capabilities as well as partnership platforms, equipping participants with practical tools for effective partnering at various levels, aimed at fostering trans

column1: SDG 11: Progress, challenges, lessons learned and tools for sustainable transformation of cities
column4: Sustainable Cities Institute (Brazil), World Blind Union (WBU), UNIBO and University of Paris Saclay International Association of Universities (IAU)
column5: This session focused on SDG 11 (Sustainable cities and communities) and SDG 17 (Partnership for the goals). This virtual session identified key themes, shared progress, and discussed how to strengthen partnerships among cities, universities, policymakers, urban professionals, civil society (including NGOs), and Organizations of Persons with Disabilities to accelerate SDG 11 implementation through sustainable urban transformation.

column1: Gender-Responsiveness in Partnerships for the SDGs: consultations, tools, strategies and approaches to overcome barriers towards gender equality
column4: Women's Major Group Center for Migration, Gender, and Justice Mediators Beyond Borders International Centre for Feminist Foreign Policy (CFFP)
column5: Concentrated on SDG 17 (Partnership for the goals), this session provided strategic insights and practical knowledge to participants on finding sustainable solutions for their communities. The session discussed in depth the methodologies to enhance dialogue, collaboration, and partnerships among various stakeholders to achieve the SDGs by 2030. The session involved panel discussions on themes including the Gender-Migration Index, effective stakeholder engagement through conflict resolution strategies, and building and utilizing NGO consultations for gender equality.

column1: Opening Session-SDG Learning and Training 2022
column4: UNITAR
column5: Opening session of the SDGs Learning, Training and Practice 2022, was held inperson at Conference Room 8, NYHQ with live stream on UN WebTV. This high-level session was moderated by H.E. Ms. Egriselda López, Permanent Representative of El Salvador to the United Nations, and featured welcoming remarks from H.E. Mr. Collen Vixen Kelapile, 77th President of the Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC), and Mr. Liu Zhenmin, UnderSecretary-General for Economic and Social Affairs, UNDESA, as well as Mr. Leonel Antonio Fernández Reyna, Former President of the Dominican Republic, as the keynote speaker. Mr. Fernandez highlighted the urgency to provide policy reform and resources to ensure universal quality education and stated that “…the learning crisis expands inequality, which creates learning deficits with long-term and lasting consequences”, with COVID-19 as our wake-up call.

column1: The 2030 Agenda and global challenges Interconnections: a reflection on nuclear weapons and SDG implementation
column4: UNITAR; Hiroshima Organization for Global Peace (HOPe); Hiroshima Prefecture
column5: This session raised the issue of the interconnections between nuclear weapons issues and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Panelists discussed how promotion of nuclear disarmament and the elimination of nuclear weapons could contribute to the achievement of the SDGs and the realization of a sustainable future for humankind.

column1: Transformative education, digital learning and partnerships towards a more sustainable and equitable future
column4: Global Schools Program; United Nations Sustainable Development Solutions Network (SDSN); HUB MY World Mexico; International Association of Universities (IAU), with ACU and AUF; York University, Canada (York International & UNESCO Chair)
column5: Focused on SDG4 (quality education), with key objectives including: exploring innovative approaches to achieving transformative education via partnerships, best practices and digital learning; providing tangible resources and take-aways for participants to implement best practices in their own context; and offering a platform to discuss best ways to achieve the outcomes in the UNESCO Futures of Education Report and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

column1: Transformational Partnerships: national platforms and practical tools to promote collaboration, policy integration and coherence
column4: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development; Ministry of Public Service, Labour and Social Welfare, Government of Zimbabwe; Division for Sustainable Development Goals (DSDG/UN DESA); The Partnering Initiative - TPI
column5: It provided participants with insights and practical tools on: How multi-stakeholder partnerships generate transformational change How to manage partnerships effectively Tracking and measuring impacts of partnerships, with focus on their added value What has and has not worked, including in relation to how funders have supported partners/partnerships in response to COVID-19 Tools that can help funders better support transformational partnerships Good practices around stakeholder engagement in partnerships In-depth case study of partnerships for sustainable development in Zimbabwe, including their National Development Strategies and 2021 Voluntary National Review. T

column1: Learning Disrupted: Reimagining Learning Ecosystems. A learning session on data, new skills, accountability and integrity
column4: International Council for Adult Education (ICAE), The World Bank, UNDP Namibia in partnership with Office of the Prime Minister, Statistics Division/UN DESA on behalf of the Global Network of Institutions for Statistical Training (GIST)
column5: This session focused on SDG4 (quality education), with key objectives including: exploring innovative approaches to achieving transformative education via partnerships, best practices and digital learning; providing tangible resources and take-aways for participants to implement best practices in their own context; and offering a platform to discuss best ways to achieve the outcomes in the UNESCO Futures of Education Report and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development

column1: Protecting our Ocean: SDG 14 and its interlinkages
column4: ESRI; American College of Greece
column5: Throught this session discussed, through various lenses, the ways by which the land and ocean are interlinked and how one ecosystem depends upon or is impacted by the other. The session discussed the effect of the maritime industry and other human activities on marine ecosystems and explored the interaction between life below water and life on land using Geographic Information Systems (GIS).

column1: Achieving gender equality: measuring progress and advocating for systems change
column4: UN Women; Women@theTable; Women’s Major Group; Center for Migration, Gender and Justice
column5: It was focused on understanding where we are on achieving the SDGs from a gender equality perspective and how, through bold and accelerated action, this bleak picture can be transformed so that we can get back on track to achieving gender equality. The session was divided into four parts dealing with the following topics: Introduction: Status of data availability on the SDGs from a gender perspective, Data Gaps/Challenges: Spotlight AI, Data Tools: SDG5 Tracker and GenderMigration Index (GMI), and Data to Action: insights from Civil Society Advocacy

column1: Human rights education, global citizenship and transformative methods to accelerate sustainable development and resilient recovery
column4: Permanent Mission of Denmark to the United Nations in New York; The Millennials Movement; The Baltic Sea Challenge; The Nordic Network for Sustainable Development at the Nordic Network for Adult Learning; The Danish Institute for Human Rights.
column5: This session aimed to spotlight how education, innovation, collaboration, engagement and research are the foundations for the future. Presenters shared examples, tools and discussed how to untap education’s potential for demonstrable change and progress. The session focused on Human Rights Education (HRE) as an integral element of inclusive and equitable quality education (SDG 4) and an essential driver for meeting the targets contained within the 2030 Agenda. The session also shared examples of transformative methods for enhancing sustainable lifestyles through peoplecentered participatory methods, community-level engagement and empowerment

column1: Sharing solutions: SDG financing, knowledge research and community participation for sustainable recovery, planning and transformation
column4: National Planning Department, Government of Colombia; CANEUS; Division for Sustainable Development Goals/UN DESA; FILAC; AJEMALEBU SELF HELP
column5: This session discussed financing strategies for the SDGs as mechanisms to optimize the mobilization of different financial sources. A global research and knowledge repository initiative called "Indigenous Knowledge Research Infrastructure IKRI” was presented as a valuable learning and training tool for SDG implementation. The session also shared best practices on community participation for sustainable recovery, planning and transformation. The session presented an overview of UNDESA and ECLAC collaboration aiming at supporting sustainable recovery and resilience towards the Sustainable Development Goals in the Caribbean SIDS.

column1: Innovative tools for target setting, peer learning and policy dialogue on SDG 4 and SDG competencies
column4: Ministry of Education and Science of the Kyrgyz Republic; Leeds Beckett University and EMJMD Genial Consortium; Lulea University of Technology; Global Education Monitoring (GEM) Report, UNESCO; UNITAR; Université de Lorraine.
column5: This session aimed at introducing the Global Education Observatory (GEO), a new gateway website for SDG 4 related information in member states. It also presented strategies to integrate planetary health into education systems in order to prevent future pandemics. The session further shared successful, innovative practices on quality world class green IT education provision models through strong collaborative joint partnerships and a SDG fitness tool.

column1: Building strong and global partnerships to achieve the SDGs
column4: Supreme Committee for Delivery and Legacy – Generation Amazing, Government of Qatar; SDG2030.me; University for Peace (UPEACE); IFRC; UNODC; International Forum for Understanding.
column5: This session approached sustainable development in a cross-sectoral manner, specifically promoting best practices and including diverse stakeholders ranging from leading academics and UN and INGO representatives to grassroots activists and educators working in the field. The diversity of issue areas and participation contributed to an intergenerational narrative to advance the full implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

column1: Opening Session - SDG Learning and Training 2021
column4: UNITAR
column5: Opening of the SDG Learning, Training and Practice 2021 and launch of the University Network for Sustainable Development.

column1: Unmasking inequalities, accelerating change: using disaggregated and citizen-generated data to foster SDG reporting and Accountability
column4: Save the Children, World Vision International, Tap Network, Kwantu.
column5: This session discussed the importance of disaggregated data in tracking progress on the SDGs and demonstrated how governments, civil society organizations, and other stakeholders can produce sections/chapters as part of the Voluntary National Reviews. In addition, this session highlighted how data on inequality can help to inform strategies and policies in SDG implementation

column1: Integrating recovery planning from COVID-19, building resilience and strengthening policy coherence towards the SDGs
column4: UNITAR, CANEUS, FILAC, UNDOOSA, GNDR
column5: This session introduced the latest methodologies and approaches established to strengthen the capacity of the participants in contributing to a sustainable recovery of the COVID-19 pandemic and making progress in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and its SDGs.

column1: Fostering Evidence-Based Decision-making for Sustainable and Just COVID Recovery and Transformative SDG implementation
column4: IISD, UNOSTAT, World Benchmarking Alliance, UK Space Agency, Geneva Science-Policy Interface, UN Global Compact, Simon Institute for Longterm Governance, Danish Insititute 07 July, 2021 Wednesday, 2:00 pm 9 for Human Rights, Women's Major Group, FEMINET, UNRISD, GRI, UNCTAD
column5: This session was divided into two parts: "Tools and Resources for Evidence-Based Decision-Making" , which introduced key components to find data and conduct basic interpretation of expanded wealth measures for countries and regions pathways to recovery. The second part "Behavioral Solutions for Evidence-based Decision-making" , showed behaviorally informed techniques that improve individual and collective decisionmaking under time constraints and in the face of complexity

column1: Tools and lessons for inclusive and sustainable recovery to secure, regain and sustain SDG momentum
column4: The Permanent Mission of Denmark to the UN in NY, The Permanent Mission of Costa Rica to the UN in NY, The Danish Institute for Human Rights, The Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Equal 10 Rights Trust, Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, Bill & Melinda Gates Institute for Population and Reproductive Health, Johns Hopkins Centre for Communication Program in Tanzania, Pathfinder International in Nigeria, Jhpiego in Kenya, ProFuturo, Education for Sharing
column5: This session discussed how policy coherence, accountability, advocacy and awareness-raising are essential to a sustainable recovery from COVID-19 which delivers on the SDGs and human rights. Participants were equipped with concrete tools and best practices that can be applied in their work and learned how these tools are enabling inclusive and resilient systems for accountability

column1: Mainstreaming SDG 16+ in VNRs and National Development Planning
column4: UNICRI, CMGJ, Government of Costa Rica, and Government of Cabo Verde
column5: This session focused on the challenges and setbacks SDG 16 has been facing in the past challenging year. Speakers highlighted that governments have been taking a step back in terms of SDG 16+, and showcased why leadership on SDG 16+ is critical now. The SDG 16 community urgently called upon member states, private sector, civil society organizations and all other relevant stakeholders to put SDG 16 as the foundation of recovery from COVID19, and build effective joint approaches for monitoring and implementing SDG 16+ across the world.

column1: Supporting Recovery and SDG implementation at local level: governance, tools and experiences
column4: Nova Law Green Lab in cooperation with CEDIS and Nova School of Law, Earth Observations for the SDGs, European Commission, Joint Research Centre, City of Espoo Finland, UN Habitat
column5: This session explored the connections between Earth Observation (EO) data and policymaking to support an effective post-pandemic recovery within sustainable urbanization. It introduced the EO principles while stressing the advantages and limitations for SDGs implementation and monitoring. In addition, the session illustrated EO data and tools included in the Earth Observations Toolkit for Sustainable Cities and Human Settlements, and shared an overview of the governance tools used at supranational, national, regional, and local levels to promote sustainable environmental and urban policies.

column1: Accelerating progress towards the SDGs through education
column4: Center for Sustainable Development, Earth Institute, Columbia University, International Council for Adult Education, and Sulitest
column5: This session discussed how education can build bridges and lead to a more equitable and justice-oriented society. The session demonstrated how SDG 4, and in particular SDG 4.7, can bring about transformative education. Panelists and participants shared experiences on what the global education community has learned from the pandemic, and how to best reach the most vulnerable groups. Further to this, panelists explored the mechanisms to integrate the SDGs using case studies and their respective areas of expertise

column1: Filling the gaps in further education for the 2030 Agenda and inspiring action towards the SDGs
column4: International Association of Universities, SDG Academy, L'Agence universitaire de la Francophonie & Association of Commonwealth Universities
column5: This session brought together different actors within the higher education ecosystem to share best practices and lessons learned for implementing a whole-of-institution approach to Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) and working with the SDGs on an institutional level, as well as the tools and partnerships that have made it possible. The session illustrated the importance and the benefits that a whole-of-institution approach to ESD can bring to a university and the reciprocal role that a university plays in advancing sustainable development research, supporting communities, and preparing the next generation

column1: Nuclear Disarmament and Our Sustainable Future
column4: Hiroshima Prefecture, Hiroshima Organization for Global Peace (HOPe)
column5: This session discussed the need to establish international cooperation at various levels for global health and environment, as well as the connection between the COVID-19 pandemic and nuclear weapons issues. The speakers highlighted that the international community should learn from the COVID-19 pandemic and must not only combat current crises, but also take preventative measures against potential threats, risks and vulnerabilities forthcoming
